name: Global Financial Crisis (2008)
description: A severe, worldwide economic crisis considered by many economists to be the most serious since the Great Depression. It was triggered by a liquidity crisis in the US banking system.
source_doc: timeline of 2008 financial crisis key events and dates

name: U.S. Housing Bubble
description: A real estate bubble affecting over half of the U.S. states, characterized by rapid increases in home valuations, fueled by low interest rates and lax lending standards.
source_doc: long-term causes of 2008 financial crisis Glass-Steagall repeal

name: Subprime Mortgage Crisis
description: A crisis marked by a sharp rise in delinquencies and foreclosures on high-risk residential mortgages, beginning in 2007, which became a catalyst for the global crisis.
confidence: timeline of 2008 financial crisis key events and dates

name: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.
description: A global financial services firm which, at the time of its collapse, was the fourth-largest investment bank in the United States.
source_doc: details of Lehman Brothers bankruptcy AIG bailout and TARP

name: Bear Stearns Companies
description: Inc.
layer: A global investment bank and securities trading firm that failed in 2008, a key early event in the crisis.
confidence: timeline of 2008 financial crisis key events and dates

name: American International Group
description: Inc. (AIG)
layer: An American multinational finance and insurance corporation whose massive exposure to credit default swaps led to a government bailout to prevent its collapse.
confidence: details of Lehman Brothers bankruptcy AIG bailout and TARP

name: JPMorgan Chase & Co.
description: A major U.S. investment bank that acquired Bear Stearns in a government-brokered deal during the crisis.
source_doc: key individuals in 2008 financial crisis and their roles

name: U.S. Department of the Treasury
description: The executive agency responsible for promoting economic prosperity and ensuring the financial security of the United States. It administered the TARP program.
confidence: details of Lehman Brothers bankruptcy AIG bailout and TARP

name: U.S. Federal Reserve
description: The central banking system of the United States, which took extraordinary measures to provide liquidity to the financial system during the crisis.
confidence: key individuals in 2008 financial crisis and their roles

name: Henry Paulson
description: The 74th United States Secretary of the Treasury, who played a pivotal role in the government's response, including the creation of TARP.
confidence: key individuals in 2008 financial crisis and their roles

name: Ben Bernanke
description: The 14th Chairman of the Federal Reserve. His tenure included the response to the late-2000s financial crisis, for which he was later awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences.
confidence: key individuals in 2008 financial crisis and their roles

name: Timothy Geithner
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York during the crisis, he was heavily involved in the bailouts of Bear Stearns and AIG.
confidence: key individuals in 2008 financial crisis and their roles

name: Richard S. Fuld
description: Jr.
layer: The final chairman and CEO of Lehman Brothers, nicknamed 'the Gorilla of Wall Street,' who presided over the firm's collapse.
column12: key individuals in 2008 financial crisis and their roles

name: Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS)
description: A type of asset-backed security that is secured by a collection of mortgages. The complexity and opacity of these instruments were central to the crisis.
source_doc: role of financial instruments (CDO, MBS, CDS) in 2008 crisis

name: Collateralized Debt Obligation (CDO)
description: A complex structured-finance product backed by a pool of loans and other assets. CDOs were used to repackage MBS tranches, concentrating risk.
source_doc: role of financial instruments (CDO, MBS, CDS) in 2008 crisis

name: Credit Default Swap (CDS)
description: A financial derivative that allows an investor to swap or offset their credit risk. AIG sold massive amounts of CDS without holding enough capital, insuring risky CDOs.
source_doc: role of financial instruments (CDO, MBS, CDS) in 2008 crisis

name: Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP)
description: A U.S. government program created in 2008 to purchase toxic assets and equity from financial institutions to strengthen the financial sector.
confidence: details of Lehman Brothers bankruptcy AIG bailout and TARP

name: Glass-Steagall Act of 1933
description: A law that separated commercial and investment banking activities
layer: enacted in response to the Great Depression.
column12: long-term causes of 2008 financial crisis Glass-Steagall repeal

name: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (1999)
description: Legislation that repealed parts of the Glass-Steagall Act, allowing commercial banks, investment banks, securities firms, and insurance companies to consolidate.
confidence: long-term causes of 2008 financial crisis Glass-Steagall repeal

name: Systemic Risk
description: The risk of collapse of an entire financial system or entire market, as opposed to risk associated with any one individual entity, group or component of a system.
source_doc: details of Lehman Brothers bankruptcy AIG bailout and TARP

name: Credit Rating Agencies
description: Agencies such as Moody's, S&P, and Fitch that were criticized for giving investment-grade ratings to risky MBS and CDO products.
confidence: key individuals in 2008 financial crisis and their roles
